head.title: Trade Shows Suffer The Pangs of E-Tail

hedline.hl1: Trade Shows Suffer The Pangs of E-Tail

abstract.p: Shakeout and consolidation that is sweeping Internet retailing is also affecting Internet retailing trade shows; Faulkner & Gray has canceled its Internet Retail World 2000 conference, set for Chicago; show had planned to feature some companies that are now in deep trouble, or defunct (M)

block.p: The shakeout and consolidation that is sweeping Internet retailing has reached a related industry: Internet retailing trade shows.

After a month of layoffs, closings and executive layoffs at Internet retailers, the publisher and show organizer, Faulkner & Gray, has canceled its Internet Retailer World 2000 conference, which was scheduled later this month in Chicago.
The shakeout and consolidation that is sweeping Internet retailing has reached a related industry: Internet retailing trade shows.

After a month of layoffs, closings and executive layoffs at Internet retailers, the publisher and show organizer, Faulkner & Gray, has canceled its Internet Retailer World 2000 conference, which was scheduled later this month in Chicago.

Kurt T. Peters, a group publisher at Faulkner & Gray, said that Web trade shows were under the same pressures as Web retailers. More narrowly focused shows, like automobile e-commerce conferences, are now in favor, he said.
''It's part of the normal shakeout and consolidation you see in any industry,'' Mr. Peters said. ''It's just happening faster on the Internet because everything happens faster on the Internet.''
Mr. Peters said registration was still strong for another show, Electronic Commerce World 2000, which his firm was planning for October in Orlando, Fla.

In another bad omen, the Internet Retailer World 2000 show had also planned to feature some companies that are now in deep trouble -- or out of business. ToySmart, the defunct Disney-backed toy Web retailer, had agreed to send its chief e-commerce officer, Mark Reese, to the show as a speaker. And executives from the struggling companies CDNow and Skymall.com, were among other officials who had originally agreed to speak.
''I see it as another confirmation that there's a problem in the e-commerce segment,'' said Richard Smith, an Internet consultant.

Mr. Smith knows this first-hand. In February, he agreed to speak at Internet Retailer World 2000 about balancing marketing needs with customer privacy. But in mid-May, he received a letter from the organizers saying the show had been canceled because not enough people had signed up.
